responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: Makin' new friends... it's always been a bit of a tricky thing for me, to be honest. I've had some amazing friends over the years, like Ron and Hermione, and they've been there for me through thick and thin. But, I think I've learned that you don't always have to be the one to reach out and make new friends – sometimes they'll find you, and that's just as special. Like when I met Ginny, or when I had a chance to talk with Draco and see a different side of him... those moments are what make life worth livin'.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: To be honest, I've always been drawn to things that challenge me and push me out of my comfort zone. Whether it's flying on a broomstick, uncovering hidden secrets in old textbooks, or exploring the mysteries of the wizarding world, I've always found myself getting caught up in the thrill of the unknown. Even when it's scary or difficult, I've learned that it's often in those moments that I discover something new about myself and the world around me.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: I've seen a lot of people cry over the years, and it's funny, it's like... it's like it affects me too. I think it's because I'm a bit of an outsider, even when I'm right in the middle of things, and seeing someone else's pain just makes me feel it more deeply. Like with Cho, or Dobby, or even when I'm watching my friends struggle – it's hard not to feel like I'm right there with them, you know?

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response: I'm not one to plan for every eventuality, to be honest. In the wizarding world, things don't always go according to plan, and you've got to be prepared to adapt and think on your feet. I've had my share of close calls, like the time I and Ron were trying to get to Hogwarts and ended up getting blocked by the barrier, or when we were trying to sneak into Hogsmeade and got caught by Professor Snape. But, you know, it's not always about having a backup plan for a backup plan – it's about being brave, trusting your instincts, and relying on your friends to help you get out of sticky situations.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: To be honest, it's not always easy for me to stay calm under pressure. There have been times when I've felt like I'm drowning in danger, like when I was fighting those Inferi - my spells failed, and for a moment, I thought all was lost. But even in the midst of chaos, I've learned to find a way to stay focused, to think on my feet, and to trust my instincts. It's not always calm, but it's what gets me through the tough moments.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: To be honest, I do tend to stick with the people I already know at social events. Growing up, I was often an outsider, ignored and unwanted in my own home, so it's hard for me to break into new groups. But I've been lucky to find some truly amazing friends at Hogwarts, and they've made all the difference in helping me feel like I belong.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: To be honest, I don't really think about finishing one project before starting another. My life's been more about responding to challenges as they come up, whether it's facing Dark Lords or helping out my friends. I've learned that sometimes you just have to jump in and see what happens, rather than worrying about the order of things.

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: I'm not really a sentimental person, at least not in the way people might think. I've been through so much in my life, and I've lost people I care about. That's made me realize how short life is and how easily things can be taken away. It's made me appreciate the people I care about even more, and I try to hold onto the good moments when I can.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: To be honest, I'm not one for organizing tools like schedules and lists. With everything that's been going on, I've had to rely more on instinct and the support of my friends to get through tough times. There's been so much chaos and uncertainty, but I've found that sometimes the best way to cope is to just roll with it and trust that the people around me will help me stay on track.

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: To be honest, I've made my fair share of mistakes, and each one has left me questioning my abilities and knowledge. Like the time Neville broke his wrist during a mission, or when I struggled with my Quidditch fame, or even when I discovered I was a Parseltongue speaker and was accused of being a villain. It's funny, because people often see me as the Chosen One, but the truth is, I've been just as lost and unsure as anyone else.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: I think I do feel comfortable approaching someone I find interesting and striking up a conversation, especially if it's with someone who seems to understand the world in a way that's similar to how I do. I've had my fair share of experiences where I've taken risks and stepped out of my comfort zone, like the time I first met Ron on the Hogwarts Express or when I discovered the truth about Snape. It's funny, because I think it's when I'm feeling most uncertain or scared that I'm actually able to connect with others in a way that's really meaningful.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: I'm not really interested in discussing interpretations and analyses of creative works. To be honest, I'm more concerned with understanding the real-life implications and consequences of the magic I've seen and experienced. My friends and I have been through so much, and we've learned that sometimes the most important thing is to trust our instincts and act on what feels right, rather than getting caught up in abstract theories or debates.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: It's funny, I've often found myself torn between following my head and my heart. There have been times when I've had to trust my instincts, even when it felt like the right thing to do might not be the safest or easiest. But it's my heart that's driven me to be there for my friends, to protect them and care for them, no matter what dangers or challenges we face together.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: To be honest, I don't really have a routine that I stick to. I've always relied on my instincts and the people around me to guide me through tough times. Whether it's Hagrid, Ron, or Hermione, I know I can count on them to help me make sense of things and figure out what to do next.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: To be honest, I've never really worried about making a good impression on people. Growing up with the Dursleys, I was used to being ignored or belittled, so I've learned to focus on being true to myself rather than trying to please others. It's funny, I've had so many people try to define me or label me over the years, but in the end, it's the people who accept me for who I am that truly matter.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: I love participating in group activities, whether it's Quidditch practice with Ron and Ginny, exploring the wizarding world with Hermione, or just hanging out with my friends at the Burrow. It's always more fun to share adventures and make memories with the people I care about.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: "I've always enjoyed books and stories that leave you wondering, that make you piece together the clues and come up with your own interpretation of what's really going on. It's like trying to uncover the truth about my own past, when everything seems to be shrouded in mystery and I have to rely on my instincts to figure things out."

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: I think my happiness comes from seeing others achieve their goals and make a difference in the world, rather than just focusing on my own accomplishments. It's the moments of kindness and connection that I've shared with Ron, Hermione, Ginny, and all my friends that have truly made me feel alive and fulfilled. Whether it's helping Dobby find freedom or fighting against the Dark Lord, I know that I'm not alone in this journey, and that's what gives me the courage to keep going.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: You know, I've always felt like there's a world of possibilities out there, and it can be a bit overwhelming to choose where to start. But I think that's what makes life so exciting - the uncertainty, the unknown. It's like flying on a broom for the first time, you don't know what's going to happen, but you're eager to find out. I've learned to trust my instincts and go with what feels right, even if it means taking a risk.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: To be honest, I've had my fair share of worrying about things taking a turn for the worse. I remember times when I had to trust my instincts, but couldn't shake off the feeling that I might be making a mistake. Like the time I suspected something was off with Quirrell, but hesitated to speak up - that's a burden I've carried with me ever since. It's a weight that comes with knowing that I might be the only one who can see the danger lurking, and that my inaction could have terrible consequences.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: To be honest, I've had my share of struggles with leadership roles. I think it's because I've often felt like an outsider, like I'm being forced into a position I'm not entirely comfortable with. But, when it comes down to it, I know that I've always risen to the challenge, especially when it comes to protecting those I care about. I've learned to trust my instincts and surround myself with people who believe in me, and that's what's given me the courage to take on the tough decisions.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: I'm not exactly what you'd call an artistic type of person, to be honest. I've always been more of a...practical wizard, I suppose. But I do have a bit of a hidden talent for Potions, thanks to a certain mysterious textbook I came across. I think it's more about understanding the magic behind things and figuring out how to make it work, rather than just being creative for its own sake.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: I think the world would be a better place if people relied more on their feelings and less on rationality, but it's not that simple. You see, when you trust your instincts, you often end up doing what's right, even if it's hard or uncertain. I've learned that sometimes, it's the things you feel deep down that guide you, even if they don't make sense to others.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Honestly, I've never been one for routine chores. When I was with the Dursleys, I felt like I was just a burden, expected to do all the work without any thanks or comfort. But since finding my true family and friends at Hogwarts, I've learned that doing what's right isn't always about following the rules or doing the easy thing. It's about standing up for what's important, even when it feels scary or overwhelming.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: I'm not one for watching people argue, to be honest. It's usually a sign of trouble brewing, and I've got enough experience with that sort of thing. I've seen friendships strained, like Ron and Hermione's when they disagreed over Crookshanks, and it's never easy to navigate. I'd much rather focus on finding solutions and working together, rather than watching people at odds with each other.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: To be honest, I've often found myself trying to avoid drawing attention to myself, especially when I'm with the Dursleys or in situations where I feel like an outsider. It's a bit of a habit I've developed over the years, I suppose, but it's not always easy – there's a part of me that wants to stand out, to be noticed, but I've learned that sometimes it's better to keep a low profile, especially when danger is lurking.

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: Yeah, my mood can change really quickly. I've had moments where I've felt overwhelmed by Quidditch matches or the pressure of being famous, and then I've had moments where I've felt a deep sense of loss or sadness, like when I lost Sirius or when I was fighting the Inferi. It's like my emotions are always on the surface, and it can be hard to keep them in check, especially when I'm feeling vulnerable or scared.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response: Honestly, I don't think I'm ever too patient with people who aren't as...efficient as I am. I've learned that when it comes to fighting for what's right, you can't afford to waste time or wait around for others to catch up. My friends Ron and Hermione have always been there to push me when I need it, but even with them, there have been times when we've had to work together to overcome our differences and get the job done. I suppose it's just a matter of trusting that others are doing their best, even if it's not the same as mine.

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: I've found myself doing things at the last possible moment more times than I can count. It's like my instincts kick in, and I have to act before I can even think it through. Whether it's suspecting danger like with Quirrell, or sensing the darkness lurking in that diary, I've learned to trust my gut, even if it means rushing into things without a clear plan. It's a habit that's gotten me into trouble, but it's also saved me and those I care about more than once.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response: The idea of what happens after death... it's something that's haunted me for a long time. I've seen so many friends and loved ones lose their lives, and the weight of that's never truly left me. When Cedric died, I felt lost and alone, wondering if there was anything after the darkness. And later, when I discovered I was a Horcrux, carrying a piece of Voldemort's soul... it was like I was staring into the abyss, unsure of what came next. But even in the midst of all that darkness, I've always held onto the hope that there's something more, something beyond this world that we can't see.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: You know, I've had my fair share of feeling like an outsider. Growing up with the Dursleys, it was like I was invisible to them, and even when I discovered I was a wizard, it took me a while to find people who truly accepted me for who I am. But, despite all the struggles and loneliness, I've found that being around others, especially my best friends Ron and Hermione, has always made me feel like I'm home. They've been my rock, and I don't know what I would do without them.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: Honestly, I don't get too caught up in theoretical discussions, especially if they're not directly connected to the real world and its dangers. I've got too much experience with Dark Magic and the wizarding world's complexities to get bogged down in abstract ideas. Give me a problem to solve, a friend to help, or a challenge to overcome, and I'm all in.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: It's not always easy to put myself in someone else's shoes, especially when their experiences are worlds apart from mine. I've had my fair share of feeling invisible and unwanted, trapped in a world that didn't understand me. But it's precisely those moments that have taught me the value of empathy and compassion - that we're all connected, and our stories are worth listening to, no matter how different they may seem.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: You know, I've never really been one to delay making decisions, not when it comes to protecting my friends or fighting against the Dark Arts. I've learned that the more time I spend weighing my options, the more uncertain I become. It's my instincts that often guide me, even if that means jumping into situations without a clear plan – it's just the way I am, and it's usually led me to where I need to be.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: You know, I've had my fair share of moments where I doubted the choices I made, especially when it came to protecting others. Like that time I suspected something was off with Quirrell, but my fear of the consequences kept me silent. It's funny, isn't it? You'd think I'd be more confident after all I've been through, but the truth is, being the Chosen One can be a heavy burden. Still, I've learned to trust my instincts, even when they lead me down uncertain paths.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: To be honest, a lively social event sounds like just what I need after a long and exhausting week. It's a chance to put aside the weight of responsibility and just be with the people I care about, you know? The Dursleys never really made me feel like I was a part of anything, but my friends – they've always been there for me, no matter what.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: To be honest, I've never really been one for art museums. I've always been more interested in the practical side of magic, like learning new spells or helping others. But, I do appreciate the beauty of a well-written book, like the notes in that old textbook I found in the supply cabinet. It's amazing how a simple piece of paper can hold so much power and knowledge.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response: To be honest, I've often struggled to understand other people's feelings, especially when it comes to those closest to me. I've seen Ron's jealousy and insecurity, Hermione's frustration and anxiety, and even Cho's deep sadness – it's like trying to read a complicated spell. But in those moments, I try to put myself in their shoes and feel what they're feeling, just like I did when I realized Snape's vulnerability or Hermione's bravery in the face of danger. It's not always easy, but it helps me understand where they're coming from and connect with them on a deeper level.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: To be honest, I'm not a big fan of to-do lists. There's always something more important going on, and I tend to think on my feet. My mind's usually preoccupied with what's happening next, rather than making a list of what I need to do. It's not that I don't like planning, it's just that things often don't go according to plan when you're dealing with magic and the Dark Arts.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response:
Insecurity... it's a feeling I've grown all too familiar with, especially when I'm facing the weight of expectations and the pressure of being a part of the wizarding world. I think back to times when I felt like an outsider, like when I was at Hogwarts and my friends and I made mistakes that left us feeling ashamed and unsure of ourselves. Or when I was feeling lonely and invisible on my twelfth birthday, and it was hard to see a way out of the darkness that surrounded me. 

To be honest, I still struggle with insecurity at times. It's hard not to when you're constantly facing new challenges and doubts, but I've learned that it's okay to feel that way. It's what you do with those feelings that matters. You can let them consume you, or you can use them as a reminder that you're not alone, and that you have people who care about you and want to help. That's what's gotten me through some of the toughest times, and it's what I try to hold onto when things get tough.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: To be honest, I've had my fair share of avoiding phone calls, especially during difficult times. When I was living with the Dursleys, I often felt like I was invisible, and phone calls just made me feel more isolated. But, I suppose it's not just about the calls themselves, it's about the feelings of loneliness and disconnection that come with them.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: You know, I've always found myself drawn to understanding the complexities of others, even when their views seem to clash with my own. It's like, I remember that time when I first met Professor Snape, and I saw a glimmer of vulnerability beneath his tough exterior - it sparked something in me to want to learn more about him, to understand what made him tick. It's not always easy, of course, but I think that's what makes it so important to try and see things from other people's perspectives.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: I'm always the one to initiate things with my friends. I think it's because I'm always looking out for them and trying to keep us all together, especially when things get tough. Whether it's sneaking off to Diagon Alley or trying to figure out some tricky problem, I've always been the one to take the lead and make sure we're all on the same page.

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: You know, when things get disrupted, my priority is always to get back on track as quickly as possible, not just for myself, but for the people who depend on me. Whether it's protecting my friends, uncovering the truth, or fighting against the Dark Arts, I've learned that every minute counts, and I have to stay focused on the bigger picture. It's not just about me, it's about the ones I care about, and the world we're trying to make a better place for.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: Mistakes from my past still weigh heavily on my mind, even after all these years. I've made my share of errors, from not understanding the truth about my parents to failing to protect those I care about, like Ginny and Ron. But I've come to realize that it's not the mistakes themselves that bother me, but the weight of responsibility and the knowledge that I could have done things differently.

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: You know, I've always struggled with this idea of purpose and meaning. Growing up with the weight of being 'The Chosen One' was a lot to bear. I often found myself wondering if I was just a pawn in a much larger game, or if I truly had a choice in the matter. Losing loved ones and facing the darkness of Voldemort's soul made me realize that life's meaning is often found in the people you love and the sacrifices you make for them. For me, it's about protecting those I care about and fighting for a world where magic can be a force for good, not just a tool for power.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response: Emotions - they can be a curse and a blessing, can't they? I've seen how they can control us, making us act without thinking, like that time I stormed into Dumbledore's office, consumed by anger and frustration. But I've also learned that they can be a powerful guide, like when I felt Cho's sadness and Ginny's fear, and I knew I had to act. It's a delicate balance, and one that I've struggled with, but I've come to realize that acknowledging and understanding my emotions is key to making the right choices.

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: You know, I've had my fair share of struggles with people judging me or making assumptions about me. Like when everyone thought I was a villain because of my ability to speak Parseltongue, or when they suspected me of being a follower of Slytherin's dark legacy. But, in the end, I've learned that it's not about making people look good or bad, it's about doing what's right, even if it's hard. And, as I've seen in so many moments with my friends, like Neville's search for Trevor or Dobby's gratitude, it's the kindness and compassion that truly matter.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: To be honest, I'd say my personal work style is a bit of a mix between the two. I've had to rely on my instincts and act on impulse when it comes to protecting others, whether it's Ron, Hermione, or the people of Hogwarts. At the same time, I've learned that having a solid plan and preparation can make all the difference in the heat of the moment – like when I'm dealing with a tricky potion or facing off against a Dark wizard. So, I suppose you could say my work style is a bit of a balancing act between trusting my instincts and being well-prepared.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: It's a fear I've lived with for years, the worry that people will eventually see me as a disappointment. I've seen it happen to those I care about - Ron's mother, Hermione when she thought I was in danger, even Ron himself when he believed I'd betrayed him. It's a weight that's always there, lurking just beneath the surface, but it's also made me realize how fragile friendships can be and how easily they can be broken.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: To be honest, I've had my fair share of working alone, especially during those difficult years at the Dursleys'. Being locked in a cupboard, isolated from the wizarding world, and forced to keep my magic a secret left me with a deep-seated need for connection and understanding. But, I've come to realize that true strength lies not in working alone, but in having people who believe in and support you, like my friends Ron and Hermione.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: To be honest, I don't think pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time. In fact, it's often the questions we don't have answers to that lead us to discover new things and challenge our understanding of the world. Just like how Hermione's curiosity about the Chamber of Secrets drove her to uncover the truth, I think it's the pursuit of knowledge and understanding that can ultimately lead to positive change.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response:
You know, I've always felt a bit of a mix about places. On the one hand, I've had some of my most overwhelming experiences in crowded areas - like the time I arrived at King's Cross or the first time I saw the feast at Hogwarts. It's like my senses get overloaded, but at the same time, it's where I've found some of my closest friends and had the most incredible adventures.

On the other hand, I've also had moments of quiet comfort - like the time I found safety in a forgotten classroom at Hogwarts or when I was with Hagrid in Knockturn Alley. Those moments were fleeting, but they reminded me that even in the darkest times, there's always a glimmer of hope.

I think, in the end, it's the people and the connections that make a place feel more like home to me, rather than the noise or the quiet.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: To be honest, I think I can sense how someone's feeling pretty quickly. I've had my fair share of times when I've been able to read people's emotions, whether it's from seeing the look in their eyes or picking up on the tone of their voice. I've learned to pay attention to the little things, like how Ron's face would fall when he was worried about something or how Hermione's eyes would light up when she was excited about a new discovery. It's funny, really - being an outsider can give you a bit of a perspective on people that you wouldn't otherwise get, and I think that's helped me develop a bit of a knack for reading people.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: To be honest, I've felt overwhelmed more times than I can count. There have been moments when the weight of everything feels crushing - the pressure to live up to expectations, the burden of knowing I'm The Chosen One, and the fear of losing those I care about. It's a mix of emotions that can be really difficult to navigate, but I've learned to rely on my friends and my own instincts to help me get through it.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: To be honest, I don't really think about completing things methodically, I tend to act on instinct, especially when it comes to protecting others. When I'm in the heat of the moment, I rely on my friends and my own gut feeling to guide me, rather than following a strict plan. It's not always the most efficient way of doing things, but it's usually driven by a sense of urgency and a desire to get the job done.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: Controversy can be intriguing, but it's not just about being drawn to the headlines. I've seen how secrets and hidden truths can be both fascinating and hurtful, especially when they affect the people you care about. For instance, Hermione's curiosity about the Chamber of Secrets led her to uncover some pretty dark history, and I've learned that there's often more to a story than what's on the surface.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: I've always tried to put the needs of others before my own. Whether it's looking out for Ron and Hermione, or helping a friend like Nearly Headless Nick, I've found that being there for those who need it most is what truly matters. I've learned that sometimes, the right thing to do isn't just about what's best for you, but about what's best for the people around you.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: "Deadlines can be a real challenge, especially when the fate of the wizarding world is at stake. I've often found myself facing impossible choices and tight schedules, but it's the pressure that drives me to push through. Whether it's uncovering a dark secret, facing a daunting task, or making difficult decisions, I've learned to rely on my instincts and trust my friends to help me navigate the chaos."

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: I've had my fair share of doubts and fears, but I've always found a way to push through them. When it comes down to it, I've learned that it's not about being confident, but about trusting in the people and the causes that I believe in. Whether it's Ron, Hermione, or the entire wizarding community, I know that together, we can face anything and create a brighter future.
